content.text:
"Anticipation effects occur when a participant develops expectations about which condition should occur next in the sequence. The participant's response to that condition may then be influenced more by this expectation than by the actual experience of the condition itself. For example, consider a time-perception experiment in which the participant's task is to estimate the length of time that has passed between a signal presented on a computer screen indicating the start of an interval and another signal indicating the end of an interval. (Of course participants have to be prevented somehow from marking off time during the interval by counting or rhythmically tapping.) If the time intervals in such an experiment are 12, 24, and 36 seconds, then one possible . . . sequence of conditions could be 12-24-36-36-24-12. If this cycle were repeated several times, participants probably would recognize the pattern and expect a series of increasing and then decreasing intervals. Their time estimates might soon begin to reflect this pattern rather than their perception of each independent interval."

From RESEARCH METHODS IN PSYCHOLOGY by John Shaughnessy at al., 9th Edition, copyright © 2012 The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc.

content.instruction: Doing more than one thing at a time is called multitasking.

hotspots.hotspot: Today's generation is often referred to as Generation M, which stands for Media and for Multitasking.
Some from Generation M think they can handle multitasking.
Numerous research studies have discovered that multitasking is ineffective.
Chronic media multitaskers perform worse than occasional media multitaskers.
Take a look at your computer screen right nowâ€”how many programs are running?

content.instruction: Procrastination: to put off or postpone a task

hotspots.hotspot:
Why?

Because goals are too long-term, unrealistic, or unfocused

Why?

Because they do not believe in their ability to accomplish tasks

Why?

To motivate themselves

Why?

To manage some "down time" in their hectic life

content.header: How can you avoid the time management trap of being overwhelmed?

hotspots.hotspot:
How?

Assess your current schedule.

How?

Learn to say no graciously.

How?

It is important to make sure you have enough time devoted to what's important to you.

hotspots.hotspot:
Are you prepared?

You're on your way to school to take a test and your car breaks down.

Are you prepared?

You've nearly finished your final project for AP Psychology and your computer freezes up.

Are you prepared?

Someone close to you becomes seriously ill.

Are you prepared?

You break your right wrist playing basketball with some friends.

Are you prepared?

You win the opportunity to represent your school at a national level, but you have to pay your own way.

content.instruction: Imbalance occurs when we spend too much time doing one thing.

hotspots.hotspot:
Balance

We are happier and healthier when we lead balanced lives.

Balance

Balance work and social goals.

Balance

Allow enough time to accomplish each goal.

Balance

Good time-managers lead balanced lives.

multiple.question: In general, people are good at estimating elapsed time.
Multitasking is an effective way of successfully completing several tasks in a short time.
Our brains are wired to engage in multiple tasks at the same time.
Students who engage in multitasking do not retain as much information as students that do not multitask.
Procrastination is great because it motivates students to study.
Avoiding time management traps can lead to success in AP-level work.
Which is the best way to avoid the time management trap of being overwhelmed?

answers.answer: Continuing to take on new projects

multiple.question: Which is the best way to avoid the time management trap of being unprepared for the unexpected?
Which is the best way to avoid the time management trap of pushing yourself too far?

answers.answer: Study for no longer than 75 minutes before taking a break
Study each subject area in 3-hour sessions

multiple.question: Which is the best way to avoid the time management trap of imbalance?

answers.answer: Create goals that emphasize work and play.
Tell your friends you can't spend time with them because you're taking an AP class.
